content: Many observers criticized the United Nations for leaving Timor-Leste prematurely in 2005, leading to political violence in 2006. President Jose Ramos-Horta called for the UN to stay for five more years in 2008 due to ongoing security concerns. Civilians displaced in 2006 returned home in 2008-2009. Australia played a leading role in this mission and has continued to support East Timor since then. Former President Xanana Gusmao is the current prime minister of Timor-Leste. Former President Xanana Gusmao of Timor-Leste, a former civil servant turned resistance leader, was captured by Indonesian forces in 1992 and later became the country's first president in 2002. He stepped down in 2007 to become prime minister through a coalition. Gusmao survived an assassination attempt by disgruntled security forces led by Alfredo Reinado in 2008. Mari Alkatiri, the former prime minister, resigned in 2006 amidst unrest but remains Secretary General of Fretilin with significant support. Former Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri of Timor-Leste, a Muslim minority, has considerable support within the country and a hostile relationship with Xanana Gusmao. Fretilin, the party that led the resistance to Indonesian rule, opposes Gusmao's use of petroleum reserves to fund a budget deficit. The current unicameral national parliament of 65 members was elected in 2007, growing out of an 88-member Constituent Assembly that drafted the constitution for East Timor in 2002. East Timor formally became independent in 2002 under UN administration after Indonesian withdrawal. The Constituent Assembly declared itself the first national parliament of the new state, led by Fretilin, the party that resisted Indonesian rule. The tensions between the president and the ruling party, Fretilin, contributed to the politicization of the police and lack of regulatory framework for the security forces. The political turmoil in East Timor in 2006 was triggered by the dismissal of 591 military members by former Prime Minister Alkatiri, leading to rioting, looting, and deaths. The divisions within the military and police forces, drawn from different districts, exacerbated the situation, with some police joining rebels in the hills. Alkatiri resigned in June as a result of the unrest. The turmoil in East Timor in 2006 led to looting, deaths, and mass exodus from the capital. The East Timor government's failed operation to capture Reinado in 2007 was a result of his persuasion of a border patrol unit to hand over their assault rifles. Reinado, though not a major political figure, had support among resentful young men due to the foreign military presence. Gang violence, fueled by high unemployment rates, further destabilized East Timor after the 2006 clashes. Many Dili gangs viewed Reinado positively, contributing to the escalating violence in the country. The instability in East Timor since April 2006 led to widespread displacement, with 100,000 people remaining displaced by February 2007. Lack of access to water, poor sanitation, and risk of disease were major issues for internally displaced persons. The Ministry of Social Solidarity oversaw the returns process with assistance from international organizations. By November 2008, 10,400 families had returned, 21 camps had closed, and transitional shelter sites were constructed. Limited access to food, water, and basic services remained a problem for returning IDPs, with increasing food prices and shortages cited as reasons for food security deterioration. Land disputes, damaged homes, and fear of violence in home villages impacted the sustainability of returns. The reintegration of IDPs into their original communities in East Timor has been hindered by land disputes, damaged homes, and fear of violence. Despite no major incidents of violence during recent IDP returns, sustaining returns and developing durable solutions remain a challenge. The UNOCHA ended its formal mission in December 2008, and the UN Security Council established the UN Integrated Mission in Timor-Leste to assist with security, political, and humanitarian issues. The UN Integrated Mission in Timor-Leste involves police personnel, military liaison, and staff officers to assist with security, political, and humanitarian issues, including support for electoral processes. The mission's mandate has been extended multiple times by the UN Security Council, highlighting the need for cooperation with the International Security Force.
